text: Gregg Rutherford of Britain won gold
with a long jump of 27 feet three and a
quarter inches let's compare that to all
the medal winning jump since 1896 there
are more than 80 athletes here spending
a century of Olympic history what do we
see here definitely a lot of Americans
own almost all the golds more than half
of all medals most of these athletes
jump more than 25 feet but how far is
that a better sense of scale might help
let's start with something we might know
a little better say an NBA basketball
court even a hundred years ago athletes
could jump way past the free-throw line
and most would be past the top of the
key but there's one clear standout here
past the NBA 3-point line is the jump
that belongs to Bob Beamon one of the
most iconic Olympians ever in Mexico
City in 1968 he jumped 29 feet two and a
half inches more than two feet farther
than anyone before an Olympic record
that's held for 44 years even the winner
in Beijing just four years ago is almost
two feet back that's one reason the long
jump is different unlike say swimming
records aren't dropping a year after a
year instead a few performances stand
out after a flurry of improvement in the
early games Jesse Owens set a record in
Berlin that would have won a gold medal
in any Olympics until 1960 Owens was
almost 23 when he made his jump so is
used to secret not exactly Carl Lewis
won his first long jump in Los Angeles
would he was 23 then repeated four years
later in Seoul then again in Barcelona
and four years after that in Atlanta
when he was 35 so what do Lewis and
Owens have in common they both had gold
medal speed and ultimately the long jump
is a speed event but there are some
things that jumpers can't control like
wind some medalists have jumped into a
headwind while others have had a
tailwind for Beeman's
this was measured a four and a half mile
an hour tailwind for all three medalists
the maximum tailwind allowed but when
Delon doesn't account for two feet and
jumping that far isn't impossible in
1991 outside the Olympics Mike Powell
jumped about two inches farther than
Beaman setting a world record that
endures today but on the olympic field
Beeman's record still stands forty-four
years later still better than any
olympian ever
